comments.body: Is it expected that pwsh's `OpenOutOfProcessRunspace` should work with Windows PowerShell rather than pwsh @PaulHigin ?

comments.author: derSchweiger
comments.body: Initializing the runspace with the `.CreateRunspace()` method instead of `.CreateOutOfProcessRunspace()` works but than it's not possible to use the cmdlet "Add-PSSnapin" anymore. I've to preload multiple powershell runspaces with the Exchange Management Shell Snapin. So this is kind of an unfortunate situation.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: Yeah, Add-PSSnapin has been deprecated for years now. There are [newer Exchange modules](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/exchange/connect-to-exchange-online-powershell?view=exchange-ps) available that don't use snap-ins available, though I don't know whether it works for what you're looking for specifically.

comments.author: derSchweiger
comments.body:
This module only supports Exchange Online and no On-Premise infrastructure - therefore, unfortunately, this doesn't fit into our needs. Since the "Add-PSSnapin" doesn't work with the newer Powershell SDKs, I've tried to open a "standalone" Powershell process with the `.CreateOutOfProcessRunspace()` method and import the Snapin afterwards.
However, if this method isn't supported either, I think that there is no chance to load the Exchange PSSnapin in a persistant runspace?

There is definitely a way to do it, though I'm not super familiar with how it works. comments.author: PaulHigin
comments.body:
@derSchweiger Yes, WindowsPowerShell is supported with PowerShellProcessInsance, but you are not using it correctly.  You should not use the default constructor but one of the parameterized constructors that sets up the internal state.  PowerShell has to be started in 'server mode' in the new process instance.  Yours does not run in server mode and so cannot communicate over the remote channel, and you see the hang.  Also you should provide the default type table to ensure common types are re-hydrated over the connection.

```powershell
PS C:\> $typeTable = [System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.TypeTable]::LoadDefaultTypeFiles()

PS C:\> [System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PowerShellProcessInstance]::new

OverloadDefinitions
-------------------
System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PowerShellProcessInstance new(version **powerShellVersion**, pscredential
credential, scriptblock initializationScript, bool useWow64, string workingDirectory)
System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PowerShellProcessInstance new(version **powerShellVersion**, pscredential
credential, scriptblock initializationScript, bool useWow64)
```

For example:
```powershell
PS C:\> $typeTable = [System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.TypeTable]::LoadDefaultTypeFiles()
PS C:\> $pi = [System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PowerShellProcessInstance]::new("5.1", $null, $null, $false)
PS C:\> $rs = [runspacefactory]::CreateOutOfProcessRunspace($typeTable, $pi)
PS C:\> $rs.Open()
PS C:\> $ps = [powershell]::Create($rs)
PS C:\> $ps.AddScript('$psversionTable').Invoke()

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
PSVersion                      5.1.19041.1151
BuildVersion                   10.0.19041.1151
WSManStackVersion              3.0
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSEdition                      Desktop
```
